body: I've created an issue for this problem: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-6127
This good change. I would vote for it.
I agree
Removed the milestone given the _do not merge_ label. Add back a milestone if/when this is ready.
2nd round of fixes according to Dusan. Please merge

Thank you - the fix seems to work. I tested various combinations (conditional break point, suspend all threads, suspend no thread). It seems the behavior matches the original behavior. I also briefly tested in a real application. I'll prepare a nightly version with my configuration and will see the next few day how the system  behaves. It improves the situation, so if @JaroslavTulach agrees, IMHO this should go in.
Thanks a lot for thorough testing @matthiasblaesing
this might be too risky to be merged for 12.6. I did only basic clean/build/run manual testing with it.

The problem has been reported to GSON guys as https://github.com/google/gson/issues/1981
The proposed fix is available as https://github.com/google/gson/pull/1993
Nice work.

The update breaks listing dependencies in at least one project for me. This is a "play ground" project and hast a big chunk of dependencies. With the updated maven-embedder the dependencies are not listed anymore.

From a quick look at the netbeans code it looks as if the `MavenProject#getArtifacts` method changed its beavior and returns an empty list.
I have a question about the "Replace length one String in String.indexOf ("c" -> 'c')" part. Are there numbers, that show the char variant is faster or what is the reason for this change?
Looks sane to me.

regarding the version comparison discussion:
there is a chance of the JDK getting a convenience method to convert from SourceVersion to Runtime.Version. This would allow NB to get rid of the enum init rituals some time in future. https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/pull/5973
Closing in favor of #3245
Thank you again!
Would it be nice to add a latest 2.5 as well as a 3.x library for convenience and compatibility?
Trivial change, let's have it in!
Thanks! Will merge.
As per comment on list, -1 for 12.6, should definitely be considered for 13.

> I have a question about the "Replace length one String in String.indexOf ("c" -> 'c')" part. Are there numbers, that show the char variant is faster or what is the reason for this change?

I was trusting the `Inspect & Transform` tool, but now I am testing if this is still true and running some benchmarks. Will update this PR soon and share what I find.

@jlahoda curious at removal of `work-in-progress` label. This something now ready to merge in your opinion?  A safe addition for 12.6, or push back for following release?
What's the status of this PR?  Push back another milestone?  Review in light of points about nb-javac bundling?
What's the current status of this PR?
@matthiasblaesing @jlahoda thoughts on this?  Doesn't seem fully resolved, but don't want to keep pushing back milestones. Thanks.
@lkishalmi please review and merge if you're happy.

Can you submit it to the JIRA and attach an example project there?
See also: https://netbeans.apache.org/participate/submit-pr.html

The overall goal of [nbjavac plan](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Overview%3A+nb-javac) is to simplify NetBeans codebase, simplify the matrix of various JDK/javac/NetBeans combinations, simplify testing. As such, the ideal future of this PR is to drop the _langtools javac_ here and replace it with *the same* (automatically generated nb-)javac as used for runtime. Clearly I am not able to do that for 12.6.
Looks good, but it would be nice to have a test (e.g. `java/java.completion/test/unit/src/org/netbeans/modules/java/completion/JavaCompletionTask114FeaturesTest.java`).

I think it would be good to have this at some point, but it does not necessarily need to be 12.6. So given the branch is likely to happen this week, we can aim to merge this soon after the branch, and see.

> > I have a question about the "Replace length one String in String.indexOf ("c" -> 'c')" part. Are there numbers, that show the char variant is faster or what is the reason for this change?
> 
> I was trusting the `Inspect & Transform` tool, but now I am testing if this is still true and running some benchmarks. Will update this PR soon and share what I find.

indexOf/lastIndexOf are still slightly faster on modern JDKs if chars are used. But there is no difference anymore for StringBuilder.append which is intrinsified and should perform identical in both variants.

For consistency reasons I often default to chars whenever possible - instead of single-char-Strings - so that i don't have to remember the details.

```
Benchmark                          Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
CharVsStringJMH.appendChar         avgt    5  4.493  0.052  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.appendString       avgt    5  4.282  0.028  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.indexOfChar        avgt    5  4.112  0.015  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.indexOfString      avgt    5  5.333  0.187  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.lastIndexOfChar    avgt    5  1.979  0.007  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.lastIndexOfString  avgt    5  2.802  0.038  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.replaceChar        avgt    5  6.932  0.020  ns/op
CharVsStringJMH.replaceString      avgt    5  6.948  0.045  ns/op
```

@jlahoda done, updated the test + I moved the two .pass files around since i believe they are meant to be in the folder for 14 and not 1.8.

@junichi11 @matthiasblaesing yeah copyright of course belongs to ASF. I've committed to other apache projects in the past and have a JIRA account under the same handle, so I just assumed I had already signed the CLA at some point. I've just sent it through.
I'll merge this later because it seems there is no objection.

Thanks for the test, but please return the golden files to the 1.8 folder - the golden files are based on the runtime platform, not on the source level (as e.g. the content of `java.lang` differs across JDK versions). It is a bit confusing to run JDK 14+ language feature tests on JDK 8, but without that, we would have no coverage of these features on 8-13. (The tests runs with nb-javac on JDK 8, so the javac can understand records, just the runtime has a different content of things like `java.lang`.)
@jlahoda roger, the two .pass files are back in the 1.8 folder

Closing this ticket as of now, let's wait for the availability of GlassFish Schema here https://eclipse-ee4j.github.io/glassfish/dtds and also redirection support for http://glassfish.org/dtds.

@sworisbreathing Could you write your exact steps to verify this issue on the issue page?

What do we gain by setting this? Everytime I saw someone messing with the default `file.encoding` the error was elsewhere (mostly broken uses of Writers without a charset configured) and changing it breaks other things. People already have to deal with different `file.encoding` settings. mac OS and Linux both default to UTF-8, to my knowledge only Windows uses different code pages. So when you move from windows to linux you already see differences.

consistency. If it isn't set, NB on JDK 18 might behave differently than on earlier JDKs. With it set everything behaves like JDK 18+.

If everything is working fine, all `"UTF-8"` strings or `StandardCharset.UTF-8`s could be removed some time in future since they would be redundant (including the surrounding try-catch).

Also: if something breaks due to the flag it should be easier to find and to fix since everyone is running with the same config. And as i mentioned in the PR, there would be the option to set it to COMPAT until it can be fixed.


basically: consistency and the opportunity to find potential issues early + if everything works as expected the option to get rid of some code as bonus

> consistency. If it isn't set, NB on JDK 18 might behave differently than on earlier JDKs. With it set everything behaves like JDK 18+.

JDK17 is LTS I would expect a lot of people to stay with it for the foreseeable future (at we work we are still trying to get rid of JDK 8). I don't think people regularly switching JDKs are the valid target group - they know what they risk and live with that. As I said already: People switching platforms already deal with changing default file.encoding.

> If everything is working fine, all `"UTF-8"` strings or `StandardCharset.UTF-8`s could be removed some time in future since they would be redundant (including the surrounding try-catch).

I would flag an `OutputStreamWriter` instantiated without a charset specified as an accident waiting to happen. As seen in JEP400 defaults change and they will change again. As a developer you have to get used to the fact, that you have to specify what you want to write and in which encoding.

> Also: if something breaks due to the flag it should be easier to find and to fix since everyone is running with the same config. And as i mentioned in the PR, there would be the option to set it to COMPAT until it can be fixed.

If something is broken because file.encoding changes, the code that relies on the default is broken - EOS. It is trivial to pass java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets.UTF_8, but it is hard to spot a bug that is caused by broken code relying on some default.

> basically: consistency and the opportunity to find potential issues early + if everything works as expected the option to get rid of some code as bonus

What you are overlooking is, that the change might break libraries. One such example is JNA - it uses the default charset to convert from Unicode (java.lang.String) to the native encoding (char*) - I have to see how it will be fixed, most probably by using `native.encoding`. If you change the file.encoding now, you will break:

- libraries using version detection to switch behavior
- libraries that use `native.encoding`

Before you now say: "Ah! Then lets set native.encoding also!" - Where will you take it from? Did you consider the corner cases?

I have pushed an update and ran this code the last few weeks. I think it is an improvement over the original code, but I maybe wrong, so I'd appreciate a second look. Thank you both for your inputs so far.

> > consistency. If it isn't set, NB on JDK 18 might behave differently than on earlier JDKs. With it set everything behaves like JDK 18+.
> 
> JDK17 is LTS I would expect a lot of people to stay with it for the foreseeable future (at we work we are still trying to get rid of JDK 8). I don't think people regularly switching JDKs are the valid target group - they know what they risk and live with that. As I said already: People switching platforms already deal with changing default file.encoding.

its unlikely that the JDK 8 situation will happen again. Updating JDKs today is a smaller task + LTSes are not far apart. JDK 8 was special. Intellij bundles JDK 11 as far as i know, spring will jump directly to 17. Things move faster now.

> 
> > If everything is working fine, all `"UTF-8"` strings or `StandardCharset.UTF-8`s could be removed some time in future since they would be redundant (including the surrounding try-catch).
> 
> I would flag an `OutputStreamWriter` instantiated without a charset specified as an accident waiting to happen. As seen in JEP400 defaults change and they will change again. As a developer you have to get used to the fact, that you have to specify what you want to write and in which encoding.

I agree, I would do the same until JDK 18. After that, the only reason to set a charset in-code is if you want to have it explicitly not UTF-8. Java has a standard now - switchable via a flag.

> 
> > Also: if something breaks due to the flag it should be easier to find and to fix since everyone is running with the same config. And as i mentioned in the PR, there would be the option to set it to COMPAT until it can be fixed.
> 
> If something is broken because file.encoding changes, the code that relies on the default is broken - EOS. It is trivial to pass java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets.UTF_8, but it is hard to spot a bug that is caused by broken code relying on some default.

exactly. Would be nice to find those problems. If the charset is supposed to be something which isn't UTF-8, it has to be set explicitly. Those issues have to be found if they exist.

> 
> > basically: consistency and the opportunity to find potential issues early + if everything works as expected the option to get rid of some code as bonus
> 
> What you are overlooking is, that the change might break libraries. One such example is JNA - it uses the default charset to convert from Unicode (java.lang.String) to the native encoding (char*) - I have to see how it will be fixed, most probably by using `native.encoding`. If you change the file.encoding now, you will break:
> 
>     * libraries using version detection to switch behavior
> 
>     * libraries that use `native.encoding`
> 
> 
> Before you now say: "Ah! Then lets set native.encoding also!" - Where will you take it from? Did you consider the corner cases?

I am not overlooking this, thats the reason why it has to be tested. If the native encoding is required it has to be set explicitly, the code snippet is in the linked article. This would have to be looked at at a case by case basis. If you know the native lib uses system encoding, you have to act accordingly. If its a web lib its UTF-8 with very high probability.

Its not a question of if, its more of a when. This has to happen anyway if code is supposed to continue to work across platforms. Some brave soul will have to test on windows + JDK 18 (or by setting encoding to UTF-8) earlier or later.

you are right (if you swap out JDK17 with 16 in your post) I overlooked that prior to JDK 17 there is no `native.encoding` property. Setting the `file.encoding` property explicitly (on 16 and lower) would no longer allow code to figure out what the system encoding is as you pointed out.

```
jdk-16.0.2.7.1-corretto/bin/java -XshowSettings:properties -version 2>&1 | grep encoding
    file.encoding = UTF-8
    sun.io.unicode.encoding = UnicodeLittle
    sun.jnu.encoding = UTF-8
```
```
jdk-17.0.1.12.1-corretto/bin/java -XshowSettings:properties -version 2>&1 | grep encoding
    file.encoding = UTF-8
    native.encoding = UTF-8
    sun.io.unicode.encoding = UnicodeLittle
    sun.jnu.encoding = UTF-8
```

So the better approach would be to test on JDK 17 having the `file.encoding` set. to prepare for JDK 18. If problems are encountered NB could set `file.encoding`to COMPAT until those are resolved.

Setting `file.encoding` for everyone to UTF-8 would have to wait till NB moved to JDK 17.

You don't need to mess with properties - there are early access binaries for JDK 18 available here:

http://jdk.java.net/18/

UTF-8 as default for file.encoding was merged as:

https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/commit/7fc8540907e8e7483ad5729ea416167810aa8747

and was already part of build 13, so is in the EAs.

For problems: Before we jump to setting `COMPAT`, lets try to fix bug, not work-around them. Once the property is set, it will be difficult to be removed, as others will start to rely on it.

> You don't need to mess with properties - there are early access binaries for JDK 18 available here:
> 
> http://jdk.java.net/18/
> 
> UTF-8 as default for file.encoding was merged as:
> 
> [openjdk/jdk@7fc8540](https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/commit/7fc8540907e8e7483ad5729ea416167810aa8747)
> 
> and was already part of build 13, so is in the EAs.

yeah. I just thought it might be more useful to have a JDK 17 testing node than having a ea JDK 18 node, given that the resources are limited. But sure, both versions would work.

> 
> For problems: Before we jump to setting `COMPAT`, lets try to fix bug, not work-around them. Once the property is set, it will be difficult to be removed, as others will start to rely on it.

i fully agree. Setting the compatibility flag should be the last resort, not the first conclusion.
I registered in JIRA, should i open it as "bug" or "improved feature"?

Hallo, I switched to the `kotlin-donation` branch and tried to build it, after having changed NetBeans dependencies to `RELEASE123` (was `RELEASE82`). After a little of effort I 'm now stuck in the various configurations (`pom.xml`) which are supposed to be inside `${project.basedir}/lib` but of course aren't:

1. `kotlin-ide-common.jar`
2. `openapi-formatter.jar`
3. `kotlin-formatter.jar`
4. `idea-formatter.jar`
5. `intellij-core.jar`
6. `kotlin-converter.jar`
7. `asm-all.jar`

I couldn't locate them in maven central repo under group id `org.jetbrains.kotlin`. 

Maybe the JetBrains guys could direct us here?

Hi @jkost, the answer is inside "hidden items" above in this thread: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1398#issuecomment-514526578. It won't solve the problem right away but should definitely give some directions.

would it be possible to only load the nb-javac module if NetBeans is started on a JDK with feature version older than the nb-javac version?

the new nb-javac would not help if both have the same version (since it is basically identical), and if the JDK is more recent it only causes trouble.

(i just closed several jira issues where users kept using nb 12.0 or 12.2 while updating to JDK 16 and nothing worked anymore - NB probably also needs a warning dialog to inform the user that the JDK is too new to be supported)

> would it be possible to only load the nb-javac module if NetBeans is started on a JDK with feature version older than the nb-javac version? the new nb-javac would not help if both have the same version (since it is basically identical), and if the JDK is more recent it only causes trouble.

The purpose of this PR isn't to change the UI or user workflow. That's completely orthogonal topic...

> (i just closed several jira issues where users kept using nb 12.0 or 12.2 while updating to JDK 16 and nothing worked anymore - NB probably also needs a warning dialog to inform the user that the JDK is too new to be supported)

+1 to the warning. Feel free to do that. It is unrelated to the question whether nb-javac is manually crafted or automatically backported. I think.
